title: 105_hr2949
content: MISSOURI AND MIDDLE MISSISSIPPI RIVERS ENHANCEMENT PROJECT. The definitions in this section include the Middle Mississippi River, Missouri River, project, and Secretary. The Secretary of the Army is authorized to develop a plan for a project to protect and enhance fish and wildlife habitat of the Missouri River and the middle Mississippi River within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary is required to develop a plan within 180 days to protect and enhance fish and wildlife habitat of the Missouri River and middle Mississippi River without adversely affecting water-related needs of the region. The plan must enhance fish and wildlife habitat in the Missouri River and middle Mississippi River region while considering water-related needs like flood control and navigation, and respecting private property rights. Required activities include modification and improvement. The plan must enhance fish and wildlife habitat in the Missouri River and middle Mississippi River region while considering water-related needs like flood control and navigation, and respecting private property rights. Required activities include modification and improvement of navigation training structures, creation of side channels, and restoration efforts. The plan includes modification and creation of side channels, restoration and creation of island and riverine fish and wildlife habitat, and establishment of criteria for prioritizing activities based on cost-effectiveness and success likelihood. The plan includes establishing criteria for prioritizing activities based on cost-effectiveness and success likelihood, as well as implementing activities using allocated funds. The Secretary will implement activities described in the plan using allocated funds and existing authority for unconstructed features of the project. The Secretary may design and construct project features to accelerate activities for fish and wildlife habitat protection, as long as it aligns with project purposes. The Secretary must integrate project activities with other Federal and State activities, while ensuring compatibility with project purposes. This section does not affect existing authority unless expressly provided otherwise. The Secretary must integrate project activities with other Federal and State activities. This section does not affect existing authority, except for the mitigation project for fish and wildlife losses in the Missouri River authorized by the Water Resources Development Act of 1986. The Navigation Project in Missouri, Kansas, Iowa, and Nebraska is authorized by various sections of the Water Resources Development Act of 1986. This section does not confer new authority but integrates project activities with other Federal and State activities. The Secretary shall provide for public review and comment in developing and carrying out the plan under subsection (b) and activities described in subsection (c), in accordance with applicable Federal law, including advance notice of meetings. The Secretary must allow public review and comment for activities under subsections (b) and (c), including advance notice of meetings, public input, record-keeping, and meeting proceedings. Compliance with applicable Federal laws, including the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969, is required. In carrying out activities under subsections (b) and (c), the Secretary must comply with applicable Federal laws, including the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. The non-Federal share of project costs should not exceed 25%, and the Federal share for any activity under subsection (b) is capped at $5,000,000. The Federal share of project costs under subsection (b) is capped at $5,000,000, and the operation and maintenance of the project is a Federal responsibility. Authorization of appropriations for activities under this section is set at $50,000,000 for fiscal years 1999 through 2004. The Federal government will provide $50,000,000 for activities from 1999 to 2004, managed by the Mississippi Valley Division of the Army Corps of Engineers.
